input:
3 communication tips for data scientists.
use stories
Use examples
Use analogies
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose & Audience
- Purpose: Educate data scientists (and technical professionals) on how to communicate more effectively.
- Audience: Data scientists, technical professionals, aspiring communicators.

Step 2: Wireframe
[Hook: Tease how communication sets top performers apart]
[Body: Lay out the 3 tips with brief explanations/motivation]
[CTA: Ask the audience about their own go-to communication trick]

Step 3: Body
If you want to stand out as a data scientist, you can’t just write code—you have to communicate your ideas so others *get* them.

Here are 3 ways I’ve found make a difference:

1. Use stories
   - People remember stories, not formulas. Frame your results and your audience will stay engaged.
2. Use examples
   - Don’t just share the model—walk through a sample prediction.
3. Use analogies
   - Connect new ideas to something your audience already knows. This closes the gap between data science and business.

Step 4: CTA
What’s your go-to trick for making technical ideas land?

Step 5: Hooks Direction Brainstorm
A. [Problem/solution]: "Why your data science insights aren’t landing—and how you can fix that with 3 tweaks."
B. [User’s own phrasing]: "3 communication tips for data scientists"
C. [Beginner-to-expert clarity]: "Learning to code isn’t enough—communication matters just as much."
D. [Numbers]: "3 simple strategies to communicate complex data science results."

Step 5B: Notes
A. Surprise reader with what’s missing in their communication
B. Direct, but functional and clear
C. Make it relatable to all levels
D. Numbered/tangible advice

Step 5C: Choose strongest direction
Combine (C) and (D): "Learning to code isn’t enough—here are 3 strategies for communicating your data science wins."

Step 6: Draft Full Post
Learning to code isn’t enough—here are 3 strategies for communicating your data science wins.

If you want to stand out as a data scientist, you can’t just write code—you have to communicate your ideas so others *get* them.

Here are 3 ways I’ve found make a difference:

1. Use stories
   - People remember stories, not formulas. Frame your results and your audience will stay engaged.
2. Use examples
   - Don’t just share the model—walk through a sample prediction.
3. Use analogies
   - Connect new ideas to something your audience already knows. This closes the gap between data science and business.

What’s your go-to trick for making technical ideas land?

Step 7: Review for Style, Voice, and Flow
- Tone matches Shaw’s direct, approachable style.
- Body includes bullets for scannability.
- Only one CTA. No repeated words or em dashes.
- Flows naturally and is tailored for LinkedIn.

Step 8: Write the final post.
